title.narrative: Conférence mondiale sur les femmes dans l'agriculture
Global Conference on Women in Agriculture

description.narrative:
Women farmers represent more than a quarter of the world's population, yet they have limited access to agricultural resources, inputs, and services. This project will provide funding to support the Global Conference on Women in Agriculture in New Delhi in March 2012. The conference aims to explore effective and innovative solutions to empower women farmers through sustainable and inclusive agriculture.
Changes in world agriculture In many parts of the world, agriculture is facing major structural changes, including the decline in farm size and the emergence of a rental land market. Growing urbanization and migration, combined with the frequency and magnitude of natural disasters related to climate variability, is putting pressure on rural livelihoods.
Poor and vulnerable women across different socio-economic groups suffer the most. They have little control over productive resources, such as land and water, or opportunities to participate in decision-making at the household or community level.
Sustainable farming for food security While there are growing national, regional, and global initiatives to achieve more sustainable agriculture for food and nutritional security, gender-related issues remain a challenge. This conference will seek to better understand and address these issues. The Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) has partnered with the Global Forum on Agricultural Research, IDRC, and the Asia Pacific Association of Agricultural Research Institutions to organize the event.
Conference goals and approach The conference will feature policymakers, women and agriculture gender specialists and researchers, as well as leaders of NGOs, civil society networks, donor agencies, and international organizations. They will assess how policies, programs, and institutions have influenced women farmers. They will also develop a road map for more inclusive and sustainable agriculture.
The conference will explore a range of themes: -women's access to resources -knowledge and technology -role of markets -value chains and diversification -household food and nutritional security -challenges of responding to climate uncertainty and increasing risks
Conference outputs will include a collected volume of abstracts and extended summaries, and a post-conference volume with proceedings, key papers, and presentations. The recommendations and outcomes will be shared at the Global Conference on Agricultural Research for Development in Uruguay in October 2012.
